p: Table 4 shows the studies on the anti-inflammatory effects of Gynura. The potential mechanisms for the anti-inflammatory activity of Gynura are suggested as follows: modulation of inflammatory cytokine production, inhibition of PGE 2 and NO production, inhibition of cellular inflammatory-related parameters, and inhibition of inflammation on animal models. As shown in Figure 2, the several potential anti-inflammatory signaling pathways of Gynura are PI3K/Akt, Nrf2, PPARγ, GSK3, NF-κB, and MAPK.
